message.content:
Verb tenses can be classified into several categories:

1. Present Tense: These verbs express actions that happen now or at any point in time. Examples include "I walk," "He plays," and "They sing."

2. Past Tense: These verbs express actions completed in the past. They are formed by adding "-ed" to the basic form of the verb, or using auxiliary words like "had." Examples include "I walked," "He played," and "They sang."

3. Future Tense: These verbs express actions that will happen in the future. They are formed using auxiliary words like "will" or "going to." Examples include "I will walk," "He is going to play," and "They are going to sing."

4. Present Perfect Tense: This tense is used for actions that began in the past and continue up to now, or actions that have been completed but the exact time isn't mentioned. It is formed using the auxiliary verb "have" (or "has") plus the past participle of the verb. Examples include "I have walked," "He has played," and "They have sung."

5. Past Perfect Tense: This tense expresses actions that happened in the past before another action took place in the past. It is formed using the auxiliary verb "had" plus the past participle of the verb. Examples include "I had walked," "He had played," and "They had sung."

6. Future Perfect Tense: This tense indicates an action that will be completed at some point in the future. It is formed using the auxiliary verb "will have" (or "shall have") plus the past participle of the verb. Examples include "I will have walked," "He will have played," and "They will have sung."

7. Present Perfect Continuous Tense: This tense describes an action that began in the past and is still happening now or has happened repeatedly. It is formed using the auxiliary verb "have" (or "has") plus the present participle of the verb. Examples include "I have been walking," "He has been playing," and "They have been singing."

8. Past Perfect Continuous Tense: This tense describes an action that began in the past, continued up to another point in the past, and then stopped. It is formed using the auxiliary verb "had" plus the present participle of the verb. Examples include "I had been walking," "He had been playing," and "They had been singing."

9. Future Perfect Continuous Tense: This tense describes an action that will begin in the future, continue up to a point in the future, and then stop. It is formed using the auxiliary verb "will have" (or "shall have") plus the present participle of the verb. Examples include "I will have been walking," "He will have been playing," and "They will have been singing."

These are some of the main verb tenses used in English. Each tense serves a specific purpose for expressing different situations and timeframes.
